articles.headline: Justices Decline Terror Case of a U.S. Citizen
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court left Jose Padilla's detention intact, but justices offered a warning to the Bush administration.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court left Jose Padilla's detention intact, but justices offered a warning to the Bush administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 3 — Jose Padilla, the American citizen held for more than three years in military custody as an enemy combatant, fell one vote short on Monday of persuading the Supreme Court to take his case.

articles.headline: Chávez, Seeking Foreign Allies, Spends Billions
articles.snippet: Venezuela's president is spending oil revenues with the aim of greater influence in the Americas.
articles.abstract: Venezuela's president is spending oil revenues with the aim of greater influence in the Americas.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Hugo Chávez is spending billions of dollars of his country's oil windfall on pet projects abroad, aimed at setting up his leftist government as a political counterpoint to the conservative Bush administration in the region.

articles.headline: Jurors Permit Death Penalty for Moussaoui
articles.snippet: The jury found that Zacarias Moussaoui was responsible for some of the deaths on Sept. 11, 2001.
articles.abstract: The jury found that Zacarias Moussaoui was responsible for some of the deaths on Sept. 11, 2001.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va., April 3 — A federal jury on Monday found that Zacarias Moussaoui was responsible for some of the deaths that occurred on Sept. 11, 2001, and was thus eligible to be executed. The unanimous verdict removes the greatest hurdle to the government's obtaining a death sentence.

articles.headline: An Immigration Debate Framed by Family Ties
articles.snippet: During the heated immigration debate on Capitol Hill, some Republicans have portrayed immigrants as invaders, criminals and burdens to society. But for Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, the image that comes to mind is that of his...
articles.abstract: During the heated immigration debate on Capitol Hill, some Republicans have portrayed immigrants as invaders, criminals and burdens to society. But for Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, the image that comes to mind is that of his mother and the day the authorities took her away.     It was 1943, World War II was raging, and federal agents were sweeping through Albuquerque hunting for Italian sympathizers. They found Mr. Domenici's mother, Alda V. Domenici, a curly-haired mother of four and a local PTA president who also happened to be an illegal immigrant from Italy. Mr. Domenici, who said he was 9 or 10 years old then, wept when his mother vanished with the agents in their big black car.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 3 - During the heated immigration debate on Capitol Hill, some Republicans have portrayed immigrants as invaders, criminals and burdens to society. But for Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, the image that comes to mind is that of his mother and the day the authorities took her away.

articles.headline: DeLay Is Quitting Race and House, Officials Report
articles.snippet: Representative Tom DeLay, the relentless Texan who helped lead House Republicans to power but became ensnared in a corruption scandal, has decided to leave Congress, House officials said Monday night.     Mr. DeLay, who abandoned his efforts to ho...
articles.abstract: Representative Tom DeLay, the relentless Texan who helped lead House Republicans to power but became ensnared in a corruption scandal, has decided to leave Congress, House officials said Monday night.     Mr. DeLay, who abandoned his efforts to hold onto his position as majority leader earlier this year after the indictment of the lobbyist Jack Abramoff, a former ally, was seeking re-election as vindication. But he told selected colleagues that, facing the possibility of defeat, he had decided not to try to hold on to his House seat.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 3 - Representative Tom DeLay, the relentless Texan who helped lead House Republicans to power but became ensnared in a corruption scandal, has decided to leave Congress, House officials said Monday night.

articles.headline: Iran Joins the Space Club, but Why?
articles.snippet: Iran's launching of small satellite in October 2005 and its planned launch of another satellite in upcoming months raises questions about why Iran is becoming involved in space activities; some experts say that satellites will add another building...
articles.abstract: Iran's launching of small satellite in October 2005 and its planned launch of another satellite in upcoming months raises questions about why Iran is becoming involved in space activities; some experts say that satellites will add another building block to move disputed nuclear program forward, while others believe it is simply part of drive toward becoming more technologically advanced nation; no country has protested Iran's involvement in space, but United States and other nations agree that it could pose threat and should be monitored; Iranian rocket programs described; drawings (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The spacecraft is small by world standards -- a microsatellite of a few hundred pounds. Launched in October by the Russians for an oil-rich client, it orbits the earth once every 99 minutes and reportedly has a camera for peering down on large swaths of land.
articles.byline: By William J. Broad and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: A CBS Deal With Katie Couric May Be Near
articles.snippet: CBS's long courtship of Katie Couric has moved close to a conclusion. A deal to recruit her away from NBC's ''Today'' show and into the nightly anchor chair at CBS News may be completed as early as this week, people close to the negotiations said ...
articles.abstract: CBS's long courtship of Katie Couric has moved close to a conclusion. A deal to recruit her away from NBC's ''Today'' show and into the nightly anchor chair at CBS News may be completed as early as this week, people close to the negotiations said yesterday.     While Ms. Couric is under contract to NBC though the end of May and, under the terms of her current deal, cannot have any formal talks with CBS or another network until the beginning of that month, NBC executives decided in recent days to permit Ms. Couric's representatives to discuss outside offers for her future services.
articles.lead_paragraph: CBS's long courtship of Katie Couric has moved close to a conclusion. A deal to recruit her away from NBC's "Today" show and into the nightly anchor chair at CBS News may be completed as early as this week, people close to the negotiations said yesterday.

articles.headline: G.M. Board Gives Chief Some Time
articles.snippet: The board of General Motors expressed support Monday for Rick Wagoner, the company's embattled chief executive, as G.M. announced a long-anticipated deal to sell a majority stake in its financing arm, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, for...
articles.abstract: The board of General Motors expressed support Monday for Rick Wagoner, the company's embattled chief executive, as G.M. announced a long-anticipated deal to sell a majority stake in its financing arm, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, for $7.4 billion.     It marked the board's first public comment on Mr. Wagoner since a spate of recent bad news, but analysts said it did not indicate unconditional backing. Indeed, accounting missteps prompted a board investigation two weeks ago after one error forced G.M. to increase its losses in 2005 by $2 billion, to $10.6 billion.

articles.headline: About the Tables
articles.snippet: The Times is changing its daily financial tables, replacing the six existing pages with two pages of analytical tools and summary information on the markets and the economy.     As part of a continuing effort to integrate The Times and its Web ver...
articles.abstract: The Times is changing its daily financial tables, replacing the six existing pages with two pages of analytical tools and summary information on the markets and the economy.     As part of a continuing effort to integrate The Times and its Web version, online readers will be able to choose from an array of new functions, including a host of interactive graphics.     Readers will also be able to receive closing prices of their stocks and mutual funds by e-mail and will be able to receive midday alerts about sharp price shifts or business news that affects them.      An illustrated guide to using the new newspaper and online features appears today on Pages C8 and C9.     Full financial tables will continue to appear in the Sunday newspaper, covering stocks, bonds, mutual funds and foreign markets.     Comments about the changes may be e-mailed to tables@nytimes.com or telephoned to (800) 698-4637.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Times is changing its daily financial tables, replacing the six existing pages with two pages of analytical tools and summary information on the markets and the economy.

articles.abstract: A federal jury on Monday found that Zacarias Moussaoui was responsible for some of the deaths that occurred on Sept. 11, 2001, and was thus eligible to be executed. The unanimous verdict removes the greatest hurdle to the government's obtaining a death sentence.      The jury of nine men and three women will move into the next phase of the sentencing trial beginning Thursday in which they will decide whether Mr. Moussaoui, the only person to be tried in an American courtroom in connection with the Sept. 11 attacks, should be executed or spend the rest of his life in prison.

The unanimous verdict removes the greatest hurdle to the government's obtaining a death sentence.

articles.headline: Justices Decline Terror Case of a U.S. Citizen
articles.snippet: Jose Padilla, the American citizen held for more than three years in military custody as an enemy combatant, fell one vote short on Monday of persuading the Supreme Court to take his case.     Four votes are necessary for the court to take a case,...
articles.abstract: Jose Padilla, the American citizen held for more than three years in military custody as an enemy combatant, fell one vote short on Monday of persuading the Supreme Court to take his case.     Four votes are necessary for the court to take a case, and Mr. Padilla's appeal received only three. The result was to leave standing a decision by the federal appeals court in Richmond, Va., that endorsed the government's power to seize a citizen on United States soil and keep him in open-ended detention.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 3 - Jose Padilla, the American citizen held for more than three years in military custody as an enemy combatant, fell one vote short on Monday of persuading the Supreme Court to take his case.

articles.headline: Chávez, Seeking Foreign Allies, Spends Billions
articles.snippet: President Hugo Chávez is spending billions of dollars of his country's oil windfall on pet projects abroad, aimed at setting up his leftist government as a political counterpoint to the conservative Bush administration in the region.      With Ven...
articles.abstract: President Hugo Chávez is spending billions of dollars of his country's oil windfall on pet projects abroad, aimed at setting up his leftist government as a political counterpoint to the conservative Bush administration in the region.      With Venezuela's oil revenues rising 32 percent last year, Mr. Chávez has been subsidizing samba parades in Brazil, eye surgery for poor Mexicans and even heating fuel for poor families from Maine to the Bronx to Philadelphia. By some estimates, the spending now surpasses the nearly $2 billion Washington allocates annually to pay for development programs and the drug war in western South America.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela - President Hugo Chávez is spending billions of dollars of his country's oil windfall on pet projects abroad, aimed at setting up his leftist government as a political counterpoint to the conservative Bush administration in the region.
